reviewText: Warning: Watching this show will make you want to go to the range!I happened to catch the last couple episodes of Season One a few months ago just after it had ended (during one of History's marathons), and quickly started to like it.  By that point in the show, there were only a few shooters left in the competition so I really got to see the best of the best.  Then I started watching Season Two and knew I had to get more Top Shot.  Also, my fiance hadn't seen Season One, but after (literally) forcing her to watch the first episode of Season Two, she was hooked, too.  So we got it for a great price on Amazon and were watching it that weekend.The show itself is hard to describe.  Sure, the shooting is what you really want to see when you first start watching, but after a time you really become invested in the competitors, too.  I hate reality TV, and sometimes the in-house politics gets annoying, but once they get out on the range and display their skill, all that crap disappears for a while.  I'd say it's split pretty even, half the show is goofy reality TV stuff, and the other half is shooting.  After a while, some of the more annoying ones go away and you're left with a group of guys and girl that you can really respect.Essentially, if you're a weapons enthusiast in any way shape or form, or just love a good show of skill, Top Shot will not disappoint.  Definitely worth the low price on Amazon.

reviewText: The political portion of this show is awful!  The losing shooters vote for two people to compete for elimination.  They seem to gang up on others too often.  A waste.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The first season of Top Shot so far is my favorite. The show turned out to be much better than I thought it might be. It's a reality show that for once, doesn't feel as though it's scripted. There's no love stories, little to no family drama, etc. It just straight up about shooting weapons and who does it best. The twist is that the team (there are 2) that loses has to vote for 2 of it's members to go to what's called an "elimination challenge", where they both have to compete against each other. The winner stays and goes back to the team, the loser goes home.What makes this show so unique is it's not all about rifles and handguns, but about a vast number of other weapons that the teams members may have never even shot before, like bows, vintage handguns and rifles, the bowie knife and more. The contestants either learn how to shoot/throw these weapons quickly, or they end up in last place and risk being sent home.Top Shots is an entertaining competition show that is age appropriate for anyone (family friendly content) with a reality show twist on it. Well filmed and not over drama filled, it's turning out to be one of my favorite television series.
summary: Loved season one. Well filmed and not overly dramatic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The show would be better if they actually had people on here that shoot as good as they seem to think they can.  I was looking forward to watching competition between some excellent shooters, but what you get is a bunch of mediocre shooters having a cat fight during much of the show.  Typical reality show mindset where the contraversies and backbiting takes front seat and the actual hook that pulls you into watching the show (top notch competitors going head to head) doesn't really show itself.  American idol except with guns!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, let me begin by saying I've never shot guns, but this show is still very engaging and fun. It's the best in reality shows--competition, real people, big egos, big heart, etc. It makes shows like Survivor pale in comparison. We missed seeing the first season on television last year, but caught the second season this year and really, really enjoyed it. The people on the second season (especially George, Gunny, Chris, etc.) just grab your heart and make you want to stand up and cheer by the season's end. We are only part-way through this first season, and our only regret so far is that it isn't longer, darn it. It's not as good as Justified (which is the best show on TV right now--to us) but it's still really a lot of fun to watch.

reviewText: While this isn't a program I would normally watch, my husband loves it.  What I do appreciate is the fact that they use many different kind of weapons, give a little history and move along rapidly.  Most of the "reality" type shows repeat, repeat, repeat portions of the show or the dialog until they lose me.  This one moves quickly, and for me the most important part is the history of the weapons, and is different everytime.  Pretty good show.  Hubby would say "thumbs up!"

reviewText: This is the first time I have seen Top Shot - only the second reality show I have ever watched and liked.  Colby Donaldson (MC) is an excellent host and the selection of weapons used in the team and individual competitions are unique, varied and very interesting.  The Shooters are required to adapt to different weapons and shooting scenarios for each completion.  The elimination competitions are also very unique and challenging. The winner of Top Shot is truly the best marksman of the all the contestants.
summary: Excellent show - the competition format is very unique.

reviewText: This is the only reality show that I will watch. The competitors never know what weapon they will be competing with, anything from rocks to the latest police/military gadgetry. Also the internal politics is fun to watch, with many of the self-proclaimed experts being humbled by shooters who have less experience.
summary: The only reality show that I will watch

reviewText: Going into the first season of Top Shot, I only started watching because I'm a Colby fan and that was it. I knew zip about guns and didn't think the show would be very interesting. Two episodes in the show that theory went right out the window. The show surprisingly gave, much knowledge towards the way of guns, and the teamwork and preformance level, proved to be far more vital to the show then I had expected.Over the course of the season, I grew to enjoy most of the contestants preformence and found the challenges to be very well designed and challenging (with only one exception, the 2nd half of ep.4 elimination challenge). The cast members developed, the right people left and the showdown's between the better half of the cast was awesome. Best of all the right person came on top, a marksmen who worked well with its team, proved to be quite skillful with every weapon, had good relations with everyone and had some good glory moments.On the whole, this season was a great intro for reality show about guns. I bought this dvd as soon as I could. Unfortunutly it lacks in the extra's department by not adding anything except material that most would've already watched, on historychannel.com. This is the first season that every reality show should have.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After having endured my dear wife's "Top Chef" reality competitions for years, imagine my joy when I discovered a reality show that my son and I could enjoy!  "Top Shot" Season One is outstanding entertainment that deals with two teams of marksmen.  Only one man or woman can win the title of "Top Shot" and win $100,000.The teams and individuals compete with many different firearms and weapons -- everything from slingshots (using 10,000 year-old technology) to the modern 9mm pistol, specifically the Beretta 92fs, the present sidearm of the US military.  Each episode features one or more weapon, usually rifles and pistols, in a grueling marksmanship competition.  There is drama and intrigue, since during each round the losing team must select two of its members who then must compete against one another in the elimination round, and the loser goes home.This is excellent entertainment that spotlights the honored skill of marksmanship.  Men and women compete for the title of "Top Shot" and reality shows don't get any better than this.  The cinematography in this one is gorgeous, as the competition takes place in the low desert.  The competitors for the most part are engaging and enjoyable to get to know.  Highly recommended for lovers of firearms and the outdoors.  RJB.

reviewText: It's a team based competition which has some reality TV aspects but is for the most part a solid shooting competition.  Get a chance to see a variety of weapons and some amazing challenges.  After the teams have lost enough members it turns into a individual elimination style show.  They have some great slo-mo shots of the guns and how they work as well as a little (not much) historical context for the weapon.  A fun show!
summary: If you like shooting competitions, this is great

reviewText: I tried to watch this series but owing to the fact I don't like reality TV shows I didn't make it through the first episode. This series is fashioned after all the reality shows on cable and elsewhere. Namely that the so called contestants have a fake enthusiasm that irks me. It seems to me there is no real competition, just staged vignettes of people shooting everything from crossbows to slingshots and WW11 weapons. If you like reality TV you'll love it.

reviewText: Not one for REALITY shows. This is different. The contestants are recognized marksmen (&women), the program is set up with great quality and the photography is fabulous- lots of great slo-mo. It IS about shooting & the clever challenges. A minor part is about the relationships of shooters- JUST enough to engage a balance. HISTORY CHANNEL did a GREAT job with this show. Have watched every episode except a few in Season 3... Have fun!!
